items.text: 在过去的两周里，做什么事都提不起劲，或对任何事都失去兴趣。
在过去的两周里，感到心情低落、沮丧，或感到绝望。
在过去的两周里，入睡困难、睡不安稳，或睡眠明显过多。
在过去的两周里，感到疲惫，或缺少精力。
在过去的两周里，食欲明显下降，或进食明显增多。
在过去的两周里，觉得自己很糟糕、很失败，或觉得自己让家人失望了。
在过去的两周里，难以集中注意力（如阅读、工作、看视频时经常分心）。
在过去的两周里，行动或说话变慢到他人能察觉；或变得异常烦躁、坐立不安。
在过去的两周里，出现过“不如消失/死掉算了”或想伤害自己的念头。
在过去的两周里，感到紧张、焦虑或急切。
在过去的两周里，担忧一旦开始就停不下来，或难以控制。
在过去的两周里，对很多不同的事情担忧过多。
在过去的两周里，很难让自己放松下来。
在过去的两周里，烦躁到很难安静地坐着。
在过去的两周里，变得容易恼火或易激惹。
在过去的两周里，害怕会发生糟糕的事情、心里发慌。
过去一个月里，我感到无法控制生活中重要的事情。
过去一个月里，我对处理个人问题的能力感到有把握。
过去一个月里，我感觉事情正朝着我希望的方向发展。
过去一个月里，我觉得困难堆积如山、难以克服。
我能适应生活中的变化。
我能应对发生在我身上的各种突发事件。
我尽量看到事情积极或有趣的一面。
应对压力能让我变得更强大。
遇到挫折后，我能较快恢复到正常状态。
即使遇到障碍，我也能继续推进并达成目标。
在压力下，我依然能保持专注并清晰思考。
我不会轻易被失败击垮。
我认为自己是一个坚强的人。
我能妥善处理自己不舒服的情绪。
我的父母曾给我定下很高的标准。
做事有条理、有系统对我很重要。
如果我不把标准定到最高，我会觉得自己很差劲。
我更喜欢整洁、有序的环境。
我会刻意让自己的做事方式更有条理。
工作或学习失败时，我会把它解读为“我这个人很失败”。
我的父母曾希望我在各方面都特别出色。
比起大多数人，我给自己定下更高的目标。
看到别人比我做得好时，我会强烈地否定自己。
只要有一部分做得不好，我就会觉得“整体都失败了”。
即使很认真做事，我也常觉得哪里不对、需要再确认。
我讨厌事情做不到最好。
我对自己有非常高的目标。
我的父母曾经期望我表现特别出色。
我担心犯错会让别人看轻我。
我做不到和别人一样好时，会觉得自己很差劲。
我常觉得别人能接受更低的标准，但我做不到。
我做得不够好时，会担心失去他人的尊敬。
我的父母对我的未来期望，通常比我自己还要高。
我会努力让自己的生活和工作空间保持整洁。
我经常对自己做过的小事产生怀疑，总想再检查一次。
整洁对我来说非常重要。
我要求自己在每天的学习或工作中都拿到更好的结果。
我认为自己是一个有条理的人。
我会因为反复检查或重复确认而拖慢工作/学习进度。
我往往需要花很长时间，才能把一件事做到让自己“足够安心”。
我很难达到父母为我设定的标准。
最近 7 天里，强迫思维（反复出现不需要的想法，如反复怀疑门没锁）日均占用时间。
强迫思维对您的社交或工作干扰程度。

options.text: 轻度干扰，不影响整体表现
严重干扰，社交或工作相当受损
完全丧失社交或工作能力

items.text: 强迫思维给您带来的痛苦程度。

options.text: 极度痛苦，以至于难以做其他事

items.text: 您对抗强迫思维的努力程度。

options.text: 多半屈服，但有些不甘心

items.text: 您控制强迫思维的能力。

options.text: 基本能控制，花力气可转移
部分能控制，偶尔能停止

items.text: 最近 7 天里，强迫行为（为了减轻焦虑不得不做的重复动作，如反复洗手）日均占用时间。
强迫行为对您的社交或工作干扰程度。

options.text: 轻度干扰，不影响整体表现
严重干扰，社交或工作相当受损
完全丧失社交或工作能力

items.text: 假如强迫行为被阻止时，您的焦虑程度。
您对抗强迫行为的努力程度。

options.text: 多半屈服，但有些不甘心

items.text: 您控制强迫行为的能力。

options.text: 基本能控制，花力气可停止
部分能控制，不努力则控制不住
很少能控制，只能延迟完成时间
完全不能控制，必须去执行

items.text: 总体而言，上述的情绪、压力或强迫习惯，对您的日常正常生活（如工作效率、人际交往、照顾自己）造成了多大的干扰？

options.text: 中度干扰，需耗费很大精力维持生活
严重干扰，已难以完成日常任务
极度干扰，完全无法正常生活

items.text: Over the past two weeks, you felt unmotivated or lost interest in almost everything.
Over the past two weeks, you felt low, depressed, or hopeless.
Over the past two weeks, you had trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or you slept far more than usual.
Over the past two weeks, you felt exhausted or had very little energy.
Over the past two weeks, your appetite noticeably decreased, or you ate much more than usual.
Over the past two weeks, you felt you were not good enough, a failure, or that you let yourself or your family down.
Over the past two weeks, you struggled to concentrate (e.g., reading, working, watching videos).
Over the past two weeks, you moved or spoke so slowly that others noticed; or you felt unusually restless and fidgety.
Over the past two weeks, you had thoughts of disappearing or not wanting to live, or thoughts of harming yourself.
Over the past two weeks, you felt tense, anxious, or on edge.
Over the past two weeks, once worrying started, it was hard to stop or control.
Over the past two weeks, you worried too much about many different things.
Over the past two weeks, you found it hard to relax.
Over the past two weeks, you felt so restless that sitting still was difficult.
Over the past two weeks, you became easily annoyed or irritable.
Over the past two weeks, you felt afraid that something terrible might happen.
Over the past month, you felt unable to control important things in your life.
Over the past month, you felt confident in your ability to handle your personal problems.
Over the past month, you felt things were moving in the direction you wanted.
Over the past month, you felt problems were piling up and hard to overcome.
Over the past month, you were able to adapt to changes in your life.
Over the past month, you were able to handle unexpected events that came your way.
Over the past month, you tried to look for the positive or interesting side of situations.
Over the past month, coping with stress helped you become stronger.
Over the past month, you bounced back fairly quickly after setbacks.
Over the past month, even with obstacles, you kept moving forward and worked toward your goals.
Over the past month, under pressure, you stayed focused and could think clearly.
Over the past month, failure did not knock you down easily.
Over the past month, you saw yourself as a strong person.
Over the past month, you were able to manage uncomfortable emotions well.
Growing up, my parents set very high standards for me.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Doing things in an organized and systematic way matters a lot to me.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Not setting the bar at the top makes me feel like I am not good enough.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I prefer an environment that is tidy and orderly.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I deliberately try to make my way of doing things more organized.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: When I fail at work or study, I take it as proof that I am a failure as a person.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: My parents wanted me to be outstanding in every area.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Compared with most people, I set higher goals for myself.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Seeing others outperform me at work or study makes me strongly doubt myself.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: A partial setback makes me feel like the whole thing is a failure.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Even when I do something carefully, I often doubt it and feel the need to check again.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I hate not doing things as well as they can be done.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I hold extremely high goals for myself.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: My parents expected me to perform exceptionally well.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I worry that making mistakes will cause others to look down on me.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Not doing as well as others makes me feel inadequate.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I often feel others can accept lower standards, while I cannot.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: When I do not perform well enough, I worry about losing other people's respect.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: My parents' expectations for my future were usually higher than my own.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I try hard to keep my living and working spaces neat.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I often doubt small things I have done and feel the need to re-check them.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Tidiness is extremely important to me.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I demand better results from myself in my day-to-day study or work.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I think of myself as an organized person.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Repeated checking or re-confirming often slows down my work or study.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I often take a long time to finish something until I feel fully at ease about it.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: I find it difficult to meet the standards my parents set for me.

options.text: Not at all true of me

items.text: Over the past 7 days, average daily time spent on obsessive thoughts (unwanted repeated thoughts, e.g., repeatedly doubting whether you locked the door).
Over the past 7 days, how much have obsessive thoughts interfered with your social or work functioning?

options.text: Severe interference; social/work functioning significantly impaired
Unable to function socially or at work

items.text: Over the past 7 days, how much distress have obsessive thoughts caused you?

options.text: Clearly distressing, but still able to hold back
Extremely distressing; hard to do anything else

items.text: Over the past 7 days, how much effort did you make to resist obsessive thoughts?

options.text: Try to resist most of the time
Mostly gave in, but with some reluctance

items.text: Over the past 7 days, how much control did you have over obsessive thoughts?

options.text: Mostly controllable; can shift attention with effort

items.text: Over the past 7 days, average daily time spent on compulsive behaviors (repetitive actions done to reduce anxiety, e.g., repeated handwashing).
Over the past 7 days, how much have compulsive behaviors interfered with your social or work functioning?

options.text: Severe interference; social/work functioning significantly impaired
Unable to function socially or at work

items.text: Over the past 7 days, how anxious did you become when you were prevented from performing compulsive behaviors?
Over the past 7 days, how much effort did you make to resist compulsive behaviors?

options.text: Try to resist most of the time
Mostly gave in, but with some reluctance

items.text: Over the past 7 days, how much control did you have over compulsive behaviors?

options.text: Mostly controllable; can stop with effort
Partial control; hard to stop without effort
Little control; can only delay completion

items.text: Overall, how much have the above emotions, stress, or compulsive habits interfered with your normal daily life (e.g., work efficiency, relationships, self-care)?

options.text: Mild interference; does not affect the big picture
Moderate interference; takes a lot of effort to keep daily life going
Severe interference; difficult to complete daily tasks
Extreme interference; unable to function normally
